elements.content: Three fascinating coordination polymers, {[Zn2(TPPBDA)­(HCO2 –)4]·2H2O} n (1), {[Zn­(TPPBDA)1/2(4,4′-sdb)]·2H2O } n (2), and {[Zn­(TPPBDA)1/2(oba)·2DMF·2H2O]} n (3), have been successfully synthesized and characterized by the self-assembly of the TPPDBA ligand as well as Zn2+ metal salts, or in the presence of carboxylate ligands (TPPDBA = N,N,N′,N′-tetrakis­(4-(4-pyridine)-phenyl) biphenyl-4,4′-diamine), 4,4′-H2sdb = 4,4′-sulfonyldibenzoate, 4,4′-H2oba = 4,4′-oxybis­(benzoate), DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide). In complex 1, the 2D ABAB parallel stacked network in which left- and right-handed helical chains coexist and array alternately (2Dchiral/2Dchiral → 2Dachiral) makes 1 give rise to a new interesting 2D interwoven network. Complex 2 exhibits a 2D + 2D → 2D parallel interpenetrated network. For compound 3, the polycatenation among the 2D layer further extends the 2D net into a 3D framework.
elements.clean_text: Three fascinating coordination polymers, {[Zn2(TPPBDA)(HCO2 -)4]⋅2H2O} n  (1), {[Zn(TPPBDA)1/2(4,4'-sdb)]⋅2H2O } n  (2), and {[Zn(TPPBDA)1/2(oba)⋅2DMF⋅2H2O]} n  (3), have been successfully synthesized and characterized by the self-assembly of the TPPDBA ligand as well as Zn2+ metal salts, or in the presence of carboxylate ligands (TPPDBA = N,N,N',N'-tetrakis(4-(4-pyridine)-phenyl) biphenyl-4,4'-diamine), 4,4'-H2sdb = 4,4'-sulfonyldibenzoate, 4,4'-H2oba = 4,4'-oxybis(benzoate), DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide). In complex 1, the 2D ABAB parallel stacked network in which left- and right-handed helical chains coexist and array alternately (2Dchiral/2Dchiral → 2Dachiral) makes 1 give rise to a new interesting 2D interwoven network. Complex 2 exhibits a 2D + 2D → 2D parallel interpenetrated network. For compound 3, the polycatenation among the 2D layer further extends the 2D net into a 3D framework.

elements.content: Three fascinating coordination polymers have been successfully synthesized. Left- and right-handed helical chains coexist and array alternately in the interwoven ABAB parallel stacked network 1 (2Dchiral/2Dchiral → 2Dachiral). Complex 2 exhibits a 2D + 2D → 2D parallel interpenetrated network. For compound 3, the polycatenation among the 2D structure further extends into a 3D framework.

Complex 2 exhibits a 2D + 2D → 2D parallel interpenetrated network. For compound 3, the polycatenation among the 2D structure further extends into a 3D framework.

elements.content: The self-assembly of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) based on metal ions or clusters and multidentate organic ligands is of great interest in recent years, due to not only their enormous variety of impressive structural topologies but also their significant potential applications. Entanglements are common in biology as catenanes, rotaxanes, and molecular knots, which have captured more attention due to the diversities of crystal structures, topologies, and potential applications. Many exhaustive reviews about the interpenetrating fascinating structures, catenanes, and rotaxanes have been reported by Robson, Batten, Ciani, and Proserpio. Besides the interpenetrating nets, more and more attention has recently been turning to another subclass described as polycatenates, which is different with interpenetrating nets in the feature of dimensionality increase.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The self-assembly of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) based on metal ions or clusters and multidentate organic ligands is of great interest in recent years, due to not only their enormous variety of impressive structural topologies but also their significant potential applications. Entanglements are common in biology as catenanes, rotaxanes, and molecular knots, which have captured more attention due to the diversities of crystal structures, topologies, and potential applications. Many exhaustive reviews about the interpenetrating fascinating structures, catenanes, and rotaxanes have been reported by Robson, Batten, Ciani, and Proserpio. Besides the interpenetrating nets, more and more attention has recently been turning to another subclass described as polycatenates, which is different with interpenetrating nets in the feature of dimensionality increase.

elements.content: In recent years, our group has been involved in the synthesis of some interesting MOFs with impressive structures and significant potential applications. Our current work on the construction of MOFs in the tetratopic pyridyl-bridging ligand system, N,N,N′,N′-tetrakis­(4-(4-pyridine)-phenyl) biphenyl-4,4′-diamine (TPPDBA), 4,4′-sulfonyldibenzoate (4,4′-H2sdb), and 4,4′-oxybis­(benzoate) (4,4′-H2oba), leads to three fascinating compounds, that is, {[Zn2(TPPBDA)­(HCO2 –)4]·2H2O} n (1), {[Zn­(TPPBDA)1/2(4,4′-sdb)]·2H2O } n (2), and {[Zn­(TPPBDA)1/2(oba)·2DMF·2H2O]} n (3), in which the structural variation from 2Dchiral/2Dchiral → 2Dachiral, 2D + 2D → 2D parallel interpenetration, to 2D + 2D → 3D parallel polycatenation is presented (see Scheme and Table ).
elements.clean_text: In recent years, our group has been involved in the synthesis of some interesting MOFs with impressive structures and significant potential applications. Our current work on the construction of MOFs in the tetratopic pyridyl-bridging ligand system, N,N,N',N'-tetrakis(4-(4-pyridine)-phenyl) biphenyl-4,4'-diamine (TPPDBA), 4,4'-sulfonyldibenzoate (4,4'-H2sdb), and 4,4'-oxybis(benzoate) (4,4'-H2oba), leads to three fascinating compounds, that is, {[Zn2(TPPBDA)(HCO2 -)4]⋅2H2O} n  (1), {[Zn(TPPBDA)1/2(4,4'-sdb)]⋅2H2O } n  (2), and {[Zn(TPPBDA)1/2(oba)⋅2DMF⋅2H2O]} n  (3), in which the structural variation from 2Dchiral/2Dchiral → 2Dachiral, 2D + 2D → 2D parallel interpenetration, to 2D + 2D → 3D parallel polycatenation is presented (see Scheme  and Table ).

The syntheses and the measurements of compounds 1–3 are outlined in the .

Crystal Structure of {[Zn<sub>2</sub>(TPPBDA)­(HCO<sub>2</sub> <sup>–</sup>)<sub>4</sub>]·2H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

Solvothermal reactions of TPPBDA and Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O in DMF and water at 85 °C for 3 days gives pale yellow block-shaped crystals of 1. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies reveal that 1 crystallizes in the space group P21/c and is composed of a 2D coordination network. There are two crystallographically independent Zn­(II) ions, one TPPBDA molecule, four formate anions (decomposed from the dimethylamine), and two water molecules in the asymmetric unit of 1. Both Zn­(II) ions are coordinated with two nitrogen from two TPPBDA, and two oxygen from formate groups in a tetrahedral geometry, as shown in Figure a. The TPPBDA ligands connected four adjacent zinc cations to form a 2D layer. With the absence of guest molecules to fill the large void space in the 2D layer, instead of forming an open microporous structure, each layer partially passes through the adjacent layers in the offset ABAB manner (Figure b). The most fascinating and unusual structural feature is the racemic complex consisting of separate left- and right-handed helical chains: one is left-handed (layer A), while the other is right-handed (layer B) (Figure c), though layer A and layer B have the same components and linking sequence. Helices with different chiralities coexisting in the same compound are reported in some literature, whereas the 2D ABAB stacked networks, in which left- and right-handed helical chains coexist and array alternately, are rare (2Dchiral/2Dchiral → 2Dachiral), which makes 1 a new interesting member of 2D interwoven networks.
elements.clean_text:
Results

The syntheses and the measurements of compounds 1-3 are outlined in the .

Crystal Structure of {[Zn2(TPPBDA)(HCO2 -)4]⋅2H2O} n  (1)

Solvothermal reactions of TPPBDA and Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O in DMF and water at 85 °C for 3 days gives pale yellow block-shaped crystals of 1. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies reveal that 1 crystallizes in the space group P21/c and is composed of a 2D coordination network. There are two crystallographically independent Zn(II) ions, one TPPBDA molecule, four formate anions (decomposed from the dimethylamine), and two water molecules in the asymmetric unit of 1. Both Zn(II) ions are coordinated with two nitrogen from two TPPBDA, and two oxygen from formate groups in a tetrahedral geometry, as shown in Figure a. The TPPBDA ligands connected four adjacent zinc cations to form a 2D layer. With the absence of guest molecules to fill the large void space in the 2D layer, instead of forming an open microporous structure, each layer partially passes through the adjacent layers in the offset ABAB manner (Figure b). The most fascinating and unusual structural feature is the racemic complex consisting of separate left- and right-handed helical chains: one is left-handed (layer A), while the other is right-handed (layer B) (Figure c), though layer A and layer B have the same components and linking sequence. Helices with different chiralities coexisting in the same compound are reported in some literature, whereas the 2D ABAB stacked networks, in which left- and right-handed helical chains coexist and array alternately, are rare (2Dchiral/2Dchiral → 2Dachiral), which makes 1 a new interesting member of 2D interwoven networks.

elements.content: (a) Coordination environment of Zn­(II) atoms in 1 with the ellipsoids drawn at the 30% probability level. The hydrogen atoms and free water molecules are omitted for clarity. Symmetry codes: #1 = 1 – x, 0.5 + y, 1.5 – z.; #2 = 2 – x, −0.5 + y, 1.5 – z. (b) View of the adjacent 2D sheets that are stacked in an offset ABAB manner. (c) View of 2Dchiral + 2Dchiral → 2Dachiral stacked sheet constructed by two identical 2D layers.

Symmetry codes: #1 = 1 - x, 0.5 + y, 1.5 - z.; #2 = 2 - x, -0.5 + y, 1.5 - z. (b) View of the adjacent 2D sheets that are stacked in an offset ABAB manner. (c) View of 2Dchiral + 2Dchiral → 2Dachiral stacked sheet constructed by two identical 2D layers.

elements.content: Analysis of the single-crystal data of 2 suggests the framework formula of {[Zn­(TPPBDA)1/2(4,4′-sdb)]·2H2O} in the 2D + 2D → 2D parallel interpenetrated network. Compound 2 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅; the asymmetric unit of 2 contains a four-coordinated Zn­(II) atom, one-half of a TPPBDA ligand, one 1,4-sdb ligand, and two lattice water molecules. As is shown in Figure a, the Zn atom is defined by two O atoms from the monodentate carboxylate groups of two 4,4′-sdb ligands and two N atoms from two TPPBDA ligands. The TPPBDA ligand links four Zn ions to form chains, and the chains link the paired 1,4-sdb ligands to form a 2D framework (Figure b). This is one of the possible modes of parallel interpenetration based on the (6,3) topology illustrated by Batten and Robson (Figure c,d). These entangled sheets are associated in π–π interactions between the benzene rings of adjacent layers. To make parallel interpenetration possible, the layer should possess some appropriate element of undulation or open space in the direction perpendicular to the plane of the layer. In compound 2, the tetrahedral coordination of the Zn­(II) cation and the TPPBDA ligand both provide the undulating elements; then 2D → 2D parallel interpenetration takes place.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of {[Zn(TPPBDA)1/2(4,4'-sdb)]⋅2H2O } n  (2)

Analysis of the single-crystal data of 2 suggests the framework formula of {[Zn(TPPBDA)1/2(4,4'-sdb)]⋅2H2O} in the 2D + 2D → 2D parallel interpenetrated network. Compound 2 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅; the asymmetric unit of 2 contains a four-coordinated Zn(II) atom, one-half of a TPPBDA ligand, one 1,4-sdb ligand, and two lattice water molecules. As is shown in Figure a, the Zn atom is defined by two O atoms from the monodentate carboxylate groups of two 4,4'-sdb ligands and two N atoms from two TPPBDA ligands. The TPPBDA ligand links four Zn ions to form chains, and the chains link the paired 1,4-sdb ligands to form a 2D framework (Figure b). This is one of the possible modes of parallel interpenetration based on the (6,3) topology illustrated by Batten and Robson (Figure c,d). These entangled sheets are associated in π-π interactions between the benzene rings of adjacent layers. To make parallel interpenetration possible, the layer should possess some appropriate element of undulation or open space in the direction perpendicular to the plane of the layer. In compound 2, the tetrahedral coordination of the Zn(II) cation and the TPPBDA ligand both provide the undulating elements; then 2D → 2D parallel interpenetration takes place.

elements.content: (a) Coordination environment of the Zn­(II) ions in 2 with 30% ellipsoid probability (hydrogen atoms and solvated molecules are omitted for clarity). Symmetry codes: #1 = 1 + x, −1 + y, z; #2 = 1 – x, 1 – y, −z. (b) A view of 2D layer of 2. (c) 2D + 2D → 2D parallel interpenetration based on the (6,3) topology of 2. (d) Schematic representation of parallel interpenetration.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Coordination environment of the Zn(II) ions in 2 with 30% ellipsoid probability (hydrogen atoms and solvated molecules are omitted for clarity). Symmetry codes: #1 = 1 + x, -1 + y, z; #2 = 1 - x, 1 - y, -z. (b) A view of 2D layer of 2. (c) 2D + 2D → 2D parallel interpenetration based on the (6,3) topology of 2. (d) Schematic representation of parallel interpenetration.

elements.content: Compound 3 crystallizes in the triclinic P1̅ space group, and the asymmetric unit contains one tetrahedral coordination Zn­(II) ion, one-half of a TPPBDA ligand, one oba ligand, two squeezed DMF molecules, and two H2O molecules, as depicted in Figure a. The coordination environment of Zn1 is completed by two O atoms from two different oba ligands and two N atoms from two different TPPBDA ligands. The flexible TPPBDA ligands in 3 link four Zn ions to generate a 2D sheet; the introduction of the H2oba ligand does not increase the dimension (Figure b). It is interesting to find that the polycatenation of the 4-connected sheets further extends the 2D net into a 3D framework (Figure c,d). To the best of our knowledge, not many examples of 2D/3D entangled structures have been synthesized for polycatenating systems in a parallel fashion. Among the known (4,4) nets in coordination polymers, the most examples are the modes of 2D → 3D inclined polycatenation or 2D → 2D parallel interpenetration. However, 2D → 3D parallel polycatenation in (4,4) nets is not commonly observed. From a topology view, the Zn and the TPPBDA ligands can be seen as four connected nodes, so the overall 2D net is a 2-nodal (4,4)-connected layer with the Schläfli symbol {4.64.8}2­{42.64} calculated by TOPOS software.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of {[Zn(TPPBDA)1/2(oba)⋅2DMF⋅2H2O]} n  (3)

Compound 3 crystallizes in the triclinic P1̅ space group, and the asymmetric unit contains one tetrahedral coordination Zn(II) ion, one-half of a TPPBDA ligand, one oba ligand, two squeezed DMF molecules, and two H2O molecules, as depicted in Figure a. The coordination environment of Zn1 is completed by two O atoms from two different oba ligands and two N atoms from two different TPPBDA ligands. The flexible TPPBDA ligands in 3 link four Zn ions to generate a 2D sheet; the introduction of the H2oba ligand does not increase the dimension (Figure b). It is interesting to find that the polycatenation of the 4-connected sheets further extends the 2D net into a 3D framework (Figure c,d). To the best of our knowledge, not many examples of 2D/3D entangled structures have been synthesized for polycatenating systems in a parallel fashion. Among the known (4,4) nets in coordination polymers, the most examples are the modes of 2D → 3D inclined polycatenation or 2D → 2D parallel interpenetration. However, 2D → 3D parallel polycatenation in (4,4) nets is not commonly observed. From a topology view, the Zn and the TPPBDA ligands can be seen as four connected nodes, so the overall 2D net is a 2-nodal (4,4)-connected layer with the Schläfli symbol {4.64.8}2{42.64} calculated by TOPOS software.

elements.content: (a) Crystal structure of 3. Thermal ellipsoid (30%) plot of 3 showing the coordination environment of the Zn­(II) ion (symmetry codes: #1 = 1 + x, y, −1 + z; #2 = x, −1 + y, z.). (b) A view of the 2D layer of structure 3. (c) Schematic drawing of the 2D → 3D polycatenated framework. (d) The catenation of the four-membered rings in compound 3.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Crystal structure of 3. Thermal ellipsoid (30%) plot of 3 showing the coordination environment of the Zn(II) ion (symmetry codes: #1 = 1 + x, y, -1 + z; #2 = x, -1 + y, z.). (b) A view of the 2D layer of structure 3. (c) Schematic drawing of the 2D → 3D polycatenated framework. (d) The catenation of the four-membered rings in compound 3.

elements.content: To examine the thermal stabilities of these compounds, TG analyses were carried out (Figure S3, ). Because of the poor reproducibility and instability of 1, the characterization and property are not described. The TGA study of compound 2 shows a weight loss of 4.31% (calcd 4.48%) from 50 to 120 °C, suggesting that the two lattice H2O molecules are released. Above 340 °C, a rapid weight loss is observed, which is attributed to the decomposition of the coordination framework. The TGA curves of 3 indicate a two-step weight loss; the total weight loss is 19.93% in the range of 25–240 °C (calcd 20.18%). The first rapid weight loss is 3.99% from 25 to 80 °C, assigned to the removal of two lattice water molecules (calcd 3.86%), followed by the loss of approximately 16.06% corresponding to the removal of two DMF molecules (calcd 16.18%) from 120 to 240 °C. The purities of polymers 2 and 3 are confirmed by X-ray power diffraction analyses, in which the experimental spectra are almost consistent with their simulated spectra (Figures S4 and S5, ).
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analyses and X-ray Powder Diffraction

To examine the thermal stabilities of these compounds, TG analyses were carried out (Figure S3, ). Because of the poor reproducibility and instability of 1, the characterization and property are not described. The TGA study of compound 2 shows a weight loss of 4.31% (calcd 4.48%) from 50 to 120 °C, suggesting that the two lattice H2O molecules are released. Above 340 °C, a rapid weight loss is observed, which is attributed to the decomposition of the coordination framework. The TGA curves of 3 indicate a two-step weight loss; the total weight loss is 19.93% in the range of 25-240 °C (calcd 20.18%). The first rapid weight loss is 3.99% from 25 to 80 °C, assigned to the removal of two lattice water molecules (calcd 3.86%), followed by the loss of approximately 16.06% corresponding to the removal of two DMF molecules (calcd 16.18%) from 120 to 240 °C. The purities of polymers 2 and 3 are confirmed by X-ray power diffraction analyses, in which the experimental spectra are almost consistent with their simulated spectra (Figures S4 and S5, ).

elements.content: The photoluminescence spectra of complexes 2 and 3 and the TPPBDA ligand were accomplished in the solid state at room temperature (Figure ). Upon excitation with 363 nm, the TPPBDA ligand shows a medium emission band at approximately 553 nm, which is attributed to the π*−π transitions. In comparison with TPPBDA, the emission peak in 2 exhibits a red shift of 11 nm, which maybe originated from the intraligand fluorescent emissions. For compound 3, the emission bands are blue-shifted by 20 nm as compared with that of the TPPBDA ligand, which also can be attributed to the intraligand transition of the coordinated ligands. The slight differences in the band positions of coordination polymers 2 and 3 might be related to the differences in the degree of π electron overlap in structural variation, since compound 2 is associated with π–π interactions between the benzene rings of adjacent layers.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Properties

The photoluminescence spectra of complexes 2 and 3 and the TPPBDA ligand were accomplished in the solid state at room temperature (Figure ). Upon excitation with 363 nm, the TPPBDA ligand shows a medium emission band at approximately 553 nm, which is attributed to the π*-π transitions. In comparison with TPPBDA, the emission peak in 2 exhibits a red shift of 11 nm, which maybe originated from the intraligand fluorescent emissions. For compound 3, the emission bands are blue-shifted by 20 nm as compared with that of the TPPBDA ligand, which also can be attributed to the intraligand transition of the coordinated ligands. The slight differences in the band positions of coordination polymers 2 and 3 might be related to the differences in the degree of π electron overlap in structural variation, since compound 2 is associated with π-π interactions between the benzene rings of adjacent layers.

elements.content: Solid-state photoluminescent spectra of compounds 2 and 3 and the TPPBDA ligand at room temperature.
elements.clean_text: 4  Solid-state photoluminescent spectra of compounds 2 and 3 and the TPPBDA ligand at room temperature.

elements.content: In summary, three interesting entangled frameworks based on the tetratopic pyridyl-bridging ligand, that is, N,N,N′,N′-tetrakis­(4-(4-pyridine)-phenyl) biphenyl-4,4′-diamine (TPPDBA), as well as Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O or in the presence of coligands have been successfully synthesized and characterized. The three coordination architectures display interesting structural variation from 2Dchiral/2Dchiral → 2Dachiral, 2D + 2D → 2D parallel interpenetration, to 2D + 2D → 3D parallel polycatenation.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, three interesting entangled frameworks based on the tetratopic pyridyl-bridging ligand, that is, N,N,N',N'-tetrakis(4-(4-pyridine)-phenyl) biphenyl-4,4'-diamine (TPPDBA), as well as Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O or in the presence of coligands have been successfully synthesized and characterized. The three coordination architectures display interesting structural variation from 2Dchiral/2Dchiral → 2Dachiral, 2D + 2D → 2D parallel interpenetration, to 2D + 2D → 3D parallel polycatenation.

elements.content: Crystallographic data in CIF format, bond lengths and angles for coordinated bonds, details of experimental results, thermal analysis, elemental analyses, infrared spectra, and power X-ray diffraction. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

The purities of polymers 2 and 3 are confirmed by X-ray power diffraction analyses, in which the experimental spectra are almost consistent with their simulated spectra (Figures S4 and S5, ).
